speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: SCENE II. The rebel camp.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Enter WORCESTER and VERNON

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: O, no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The liberal and kind offer of the king.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: 'Twere best he did.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Then are we all undone.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: It is not possible, it cannot be,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The king should keep his word in loving us;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: He will suspect us still and find a time

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To punish this offence in other faults:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Suspicion all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For treason is but trusted like the fox,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Who, ne'er so tame, so cherish'd and lock'd up,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Will have a wild trick of his ancestors.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Look how we can, or sad or merrily,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Interpretation will misquote our looks,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And we shall feed like oxen at a stall,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The better cherish'd, still the nearer death.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: My nephew's trespass may be well forgot;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: it hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And an adopted name of privilege,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: A hair-brain'd Hotspur, govern'd by a spleen:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: All his offences live upon my head

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And on his father's; we did train him on,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And, his corruption being ta'en from us,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: We, as the spring of all, shall pay for all.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Therefore, good cousin, let not Harry know,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: In any case, the offer of the king.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Deliver what you will; I'll say 'tis so.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Here comes your cousin.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Enter HOTSPUR and DOUGLAS

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My uncle is return'd:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Uncle, what news?

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The king will bid you battle presently.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Defy him by the Lord of Westmoreland.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Lord Douglas, go you and tell him so.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Marry, and shall, and very willingly.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: There is no seeming mercy in the king.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Did you beg any? God forbid!

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I told him gently of our grievances,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Of his oath-breaking; which he mended thus,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: By now forswearing that he is forsworn:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: He calls us rebels, traitors; and will scourge

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: With haughty arms this hateful name in us.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Re-enter the EARL OF DOUGLAS

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Arm, gentlemen; to arms! for I have thrown

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: A brave defiance in King Henry's teeth,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: And Westmoreland, that was engaged, did bear it;

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Which cannot choose but bring him quickly on.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The Prince of Wales stepp'd forth before the king,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And, nephew, challenged you to single fight.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O, would the quarrel lay upon our heads,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And that no man might draw short breath today

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But I and Harry Monmouth! Tell me, tell me,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: How show'd his tasking? seem'd it in contempt?

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: No, by my soul; I never in my life

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Did hear a challenge urged more modestly,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Unless a brother should a brother dare

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: To gentle exercise and proof of arms.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: He gave you all the duties of a man;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Trimm'd up your praises with a princely tongue,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Spoke to your deservings like a chronicle,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Making you ever better than his praise

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: By still dispraising praise valued in you;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And, which became him like a prince indeed,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: He made a blushing cital of himself;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And chid his truant youth with such a grace

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: As if he master'd there a double spirit.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Of teaching and of learning instantly.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: There did he pause: but let me tell the world,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: If he outlive the envy of this day,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: England did never owe so sweet a hope,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: So much misconstrued in his wantonness.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Cousin, I think thou art enamoured

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: On his follies: never did I hear

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of any prince so wild a libertine.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But be he as he will, yet once ere night

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I will embrace him with a soldier's arm,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That he shall shrink under my courtesy.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Arm, arm with speed: and, fellows, soldiers, friends,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Better consider what you have to do

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Than I, that have not well the gift of tongue,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Can lift your blood up with persuasion.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, here are letters for you.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I cannot read them now.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O gentlemen, the time of life is short!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To spend that shortness basely were too long,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If life did ride upon a dial's point,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Still ending at the arrival of an hour.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: An if we live, we live to tread on kings;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If die, brave death, when princes die with us!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Now, for our consciences, the arms are fair,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When the intent of bearing them is just.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, prepare; the king comes on apace.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I thank him, that he cuts me from my tale,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: For I profess not talking; only this--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Let each man do his best: and here draw I

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A sword, whose temper I intend to stain

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: With the best blood that I can meet withal

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In the adventure of this perilous day.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Now, Esperance! Percy! and set on.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Sound all the lofty instruments of war,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And by that music let us all embrace;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: For, heaven to earth, some of us never shall

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A second time do such a courtesy.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The trumpets sound. They embrace, and exeunt
